intent: Added multi-platform build matrix for Linux, macOS, and Windows
reasoning_trace:
Added a separate build job that runs on multiple platforms to ensure cross-platform compatibility.

Structure:
- The existing 'test' job remains on Ubuntu and handles linting, formatting, and tests
- The new 'build' job uses a matrix strategy to build and test on:
  - ubuntu-latest (Linux)
  - macos-latest (macOS)
  - windows-latest (Windows)

Key decisions:
1. Used fail-fast: false so all platforms complete even if one fails - this gives full visibility into platform-specific issues
2. Used --release flag for builds to catch release-only issues and verify optimized builds work
3. Kept lint/fmt checks in the Ubuntu-only job since they're platform-independent
4. Each platform job runs tests too, since test behavior can differ across OSes (filesystem, paths, etc.)

Trade-offs:
- Pro: Catches platform-specific build issues before merge
- Pro: Tests run on all platforms, catching OS-specific bugs
- Con: Increases total CI time (though jobs run in parallel)
- Con: Uses more GitHub Actions minutes

The matrix runs all three platforms in parallel, so wall-clock time increase is minimal despite running 3x the builds.

rejected_alternatives.name: Single job with conditional steps per OS (harder to read, doesn't parallelize)
Only testing on Linux (misses platform-specific issues)
Using fail-fast: true (would hide issues on other platforms)
Debug builds only (misses release-mode optimization bugs)
